%280%2C0%2C0%2C%2E6%29%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcaption%20%2Ebtn%7Btext%2Dshadow%3Anone%7D%40media%20screen%20and%20%28min%2Dwidth%3A768px%29%7B%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dleft%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dright%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dnext%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dprev%7Bwidth%3A30px%3Bheight%3A30px%3Bmargin%2Dtop%3A%2D15px%3Bfont%2Dsize%3A30px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dleft%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dprev%7Bmargin%2Dleft%3A%2D15px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dright%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dnext%7Bmargin%2Dright%3A%2D15px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcaption%7Bright%3A20%25%3Bleft%3A20%25%3Bpadding%2Dbottom%3A30px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dindicators%7Bbottom%3A20px%7D%7D%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%2Dvertical%3E%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%3Aafter%2C%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%2Dvertical%3E%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%3Abefore%2C%2Ebtn%2Dtoolbar%3Aafter%2C%2Ebtn%2Dtoolbar%3Abefore%2C%2Eclearfix%3Aafter%2C%2Eclearfix%3Abefore%2C%2Econtainer%2Dfluid%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%2Dfluid%3Abefore%2C%2Econtainer%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%3Abefore%2C%2Edl%2Dhorizontal%20dd%3Aafter%2C%2Edl%2Dhorizontal%20dd%3Abefore%2C%2Eform%2Dhorizontal%20%2Eform%2Dgroup%3Aafter%2C%2Eform%2Dhorizontal%20%2Eform%2Dgroup%3Abefore%2C%2Emodal%2Dfooter%3Aafter%2C%2Emodal%2Dfooter%3Abefore%2C%2Enav%3Aafter%2C%2Enav%3Abefore%2C%2Enavbar%2Dcollapse%3Aafter%2C%2Enavbar%2Dcollapse%3Abefore%2C%2Enavbar%2Dheader%3Aafter%2C%2Enavbar%2Dheader%3Abefore%2C%2Enavbar%3Aafter%2C%2Enavbar%3Abefore%2C%2Epager%3Aafter%2C%2Epager%3Abefore%2C%2Epanel%2Dbody%3Aafter%2C%2Epanel%2Dbody%3Abefore%2C%2Erow%3Aafter%2C%2Erow%3Abefore%7Bdisplay%3Atable%3Bcontent%3A%22%20%22%7D%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%2Dvertical%3E%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%3Aafter%2C%2Ebtn%2Dtoolbar%3Aafter%2C%2Eclearfix%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%2Dfluid%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%3Aafter%2C%2Edl%2Dhorizontal%20dd%3Aafter%2C%2Eform%2Dhorizontal%20%2Eform%2Dgroup%3Aafter%2C%2Emodal%2Dfooter%3Aafter%2C%2Enav%3Aafter%2C%2Enavbar%2Dcollapse%3Aafte <div class="fluid-row" id="header">
<h1 class="title toc-ignore">Introduction to R</h1> <h4 class="author"><em>CMSC320</em></h4> <h4 class="date"><em>2016-08-31</em></h4>
</div>
<p>R is a computational environment for data analysis. It is designed around a <em>functional</em> language, as opposed to <em>procedural</em> languages like Java or C, that has desirable properties for the type of operations and workflows that are frequently performed in the course of analyzing datasets. In this exercise we will start learning some of those desirable properties while performing an analysis of a real dataset.</p> <div id="some-history" class="section level2"> <h2>Some history</h2> <p>R is an offspring of S, a language created in AT&T Labs by John Chambers (now at Stanford) and others in 1976 with the goal of creating an environment for statistical computing and data analysis. The standard for the language in current use was settled in 1998. That same year, S won the ACM Software System award, awarded to software systems that have a lasting influence, reflected in contributions to concepts, in commercial acceptance, or both.</p> <p>In 1991, Robert Gentleman and Ross Ihaka created R to provide an open source implementation of the S language and environment. They also redesigned the language to enforce lexical scoping rules. It has been maintained by the R core group since 1997, and in 2015 an R consortium, including Microsoft, Google, and others, was created.</p> <p>Along with Python it is one of the most popular environments for data analysis (e.g., figure below from <a href="http://www.kdnuggets.com/2016/06/r-python-top-analytics-data-mining-data-science-software.html">KDNuggets 2016 software survey</a>) <img src="data:image/jpeg;base64," alt /><!-- --></p> <p>We use it for this class because we find that besides it being a state-of-the-art data analysis environment, it provides a clean end-to-end platform for teaching material across the data management-modeling-communication spectrum that we study in class.</p> </div> <div id="availability-and-eco-system" class="section level2"> <h2>Availability and eco-system</h2> <p>R is freely available at <a href="http://www.r-project.org/" class="uri">http://www.r-project.org/</a>. A number of good IDEs are available for its use:</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://rstudio.org">Rstudio</a><br /> </li> <li><a href="http://www.revolutionanalytics.com/get-revolution-r">Revolution R</a></li> </ul> <p>You can also find bindings for commonly used editors and IDEs, like <a href="http://ess.r-project.org/">emacs</a> and <a href="http://www.walware.de/goto/statet">eclipse</a>.</p> <p>Resources for learning and reading about R are listed in our <a href="http://www.hcbravo.org/IntroDataScience/resources/">course page</a>. Of note are the <a href="http://swirlstats.com/">swirl project</a> and DataCamps [introduction to R] course.</p> <p>One of the biggest strengths of the R ecosystem is the variety and quality of packages for data analysis available. R uses a package system (like Python and Ruby for instance). Packages are divided into two classes: <strong>base</strong> which are packages installed when R is installed, includes packages for basic statistics, computing with probability distributions, plotting and graphics, matrix manipulations and other), all other packages are available in <a href="http://cran.r-project.org">CRAN</a>. We will be using a fair number of these packages through the course of the semester.</p> </div> <div id="how-to-think-about-r" class="section level2"> <h2>How to think about R</h2> <p>As we wrote previously, R is an environment for data analysis, centered around a <em>functional</em> language designed for common operations in data analysis. When we say that R is a <em>functional</em> language, at its most basic definition, means that we treat <em>functions</em> as values. For instance, we can assign <em>functions</em> to variables, or pass <em>functions</em> as arguments to other <em>functions</em>. Well see examples of that later on. If you are familiar with Ruby or Python, while they are not functional languages, they do have some idioms of functional languages that may be familiar: <a href="http://www.sitepoint.com/functional-programming-techniques-with-ruby-part-i/" class="uri">http://www.sitepoint.com/functional-programming-techniques-with-ruby-part-i/</a>, <a href="https://docs.python.org/2/howto/functional.html" class="uri">https://docs.python.org/2/howto/functional.html</a>.</p> <p>With that in mind, its useful to think of R as supporting three ways of thinking how to organize computation:</p> <ol style="list-style-type: decimal"> <li>Functions and lists, in the <em>functional</em> language sense described above,<br /> </li> <li>Numerical computation, operations over vectors, matrices and similar mathematical structures,<br /> </li> <li>Operations over <em>data tables</em> (think spreadsheets in Excel, or individual tables in a database). We will start our introduction to R here.</li> </ol> </div> <div id="literate-programming" class="section level2"> <h2>Literate Programming</h2> <p>One last note before we get started. R has great support for <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literate_programming">literate programming</a>, where source code that contains both code, the result of evaluating that code, and text explaining that code co-exist in a single document. This is extremely valuable in data analysis, as many choices made by data analysts are worth explaning in text, and interpretation of the results of analyses can co-exist with the computations used in that analysis. This document you are reading contains both text and code. In class, we will use <a href="http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com/">Rmarkdown</a> for this purpose.</p> </div> <div id="a-simple-data-analysis-to-get-us-going" class="section level2"> <h2>A simple data analysis to get us going</h2> <p>Im going to do a very simple analysis of Baltimore crime to show off R. Well use data downloaded from Baltimore Citys awesome open data site (this was downloaded a couple of years ago so if you download now, you will get different results).</p> <p>The repository for this particular data is here. <a href="https://data.baltimorecity.gov/Crime/BPD-Arrests/3i3v-ibrt" class="uri">https://data.baltimorecity.gov/Crime/BPD-Arrests/3i3v-ibrt</a></p> <p>First, make sure you can get Rstudio running. See <a href="http://www.hcbravo.org/IntroDataSci/homeworks/rocker/">this page</a> for instructions.</p> <p>We recommend that you use Rstudio for this class. Once open you will see Rstudio is organized into multiple panes. You will have a console into which you can write and execute commands directly. You will also have an editor pane where you can edit R source code. R scripts (only containing commands) are stored in <code>.R</code> files, Rmarkdown files (containing both commands and text) are stored in <code>.Rmd</code> files. You can follow along by writing commands shown here either in an <code>R</code>, or <code>Rmd</code> file and executing commands from the editor pane.</p> <div id="getting-data" class="section level3"> <h3>Getting data</h3> <p>Weve prepared the data previously into a comma-separated value file (<code>.csv</code> file). In this format, each line contains <em>attribute</em> values (separated by commas) for one <em>entity</em> in our dataset. Which we can download and load into our R environment.</p> <pre class="r"><code>if (!file.exists("BPD_Arrests.csv")) { download.file("http://www.hcbravo.org/IntroDataSci/misc/BPD_Arrests.csv", destfile="BPD_Arrests.csv") }</code></pre> <p>The <code>read.csv</code> command is part of base R and allows you to read a dataset stored in a csv file. This function is extremely versatile, and you can read more about it by using the standard help system in R: <code>?read.csv</code>. Now, the result of running calling this function is the data itself, so, by running the function in the console, the result of the function is printed.</p> </div> <div id="variables-and-value" class="section level3"> <h3>Variables and Value</h3> <p>To make use of this dataset we want to assign the result of calling <code>read.csv</code> (i.e., the dataset) to a variable:</p> <pre class="r"><code>arrest_tab <- read.csv("BPD_Arrests.csv", stringsAsFactors=FALSE)</code></pre> <p>Now we can ask what <em>type</em> of value is stored in the <code>arrest_tab</code> variable:</p> <pre class="r"><code>class(arrest_tab)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "data.frame"</code></pre> <p>The <code>data.frame</code> is a workhorse data structure in R. It encapsulates the idea of <em>entities</em> (in rows) and <em>attribute values</em> (in columns). We can ask other features of this dataset:</p> <pre class="r"><code># This is a comment in R, by the way
# How many rows (entities) does this dataset contain? nrow(arrest_tab)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 104528</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># How many columns (attributes)? ncol(arrest_tab)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 15</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># What are the names of those columns? colnames(arrest_tab)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "arrest" "age" "sex" ## [4] "race" "arrestDate" "arrestTime" ## [7] "arrestLocation" "incidentOffense" "incidentLocation" ## [10] "charge" "chargeDescription" "district" ## [13] "post" "neighborhood" "Location.1"</code></pre> <p>Now, in Rstudio you can view the data frame using <code>View(arrest_tab)</code>, which can be very useful.</p> </div> <div id="indexing" class="section level3"> <h3>Indexing</h3> <p>Now a basic operation in data analysis is selecting subsets of a dataset. For that we can use a few alternative options for <em>indexing</em> into datasets.</p> <pre class="r"><code># to obtain the value in the first row, fifth column: arrest_tab[1,5]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "01/01/2011"</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># note that indexing in R is 1-based, not 0-based, so the first row is indexed by 1
# now we want to do a bit more, so let's say we want the value in the fifth column of our dataset for the first 10 rows. For that we can use slice notation: arrest_tab[1:10,5]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011" ## [6] "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011" "01/01/2011"</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># similarly, to obtain the value in the first five columns of the first row arrest_tab[1,1:5]</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate ## 1 11126858 23 B M 01/01/2011</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># what is the class of the value when we subset a single column? class(arrest_tab[1:10,5])</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "character"</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># what is the class of the value when we subset a single row? class(arrest_tab[1,1:5])</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "data.frame"</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># what do we get with this indexing? arrest_tab[1:10,1:5]</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate ## 1 11126858 23 B M 01/01/2011 ## 2 11127013 37 B M 01/01/2011 ## 3 11126887 46 B M 01/01/2011 ## 4 11126873 50 B M 01/01/2011 ## 5 11126968 33 B M 01/01/2011 ## 6 11127041 41 B M 01/01/2011 ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 ## 8 11126940 20 W M 01/01/2011 ## 9 11127051 24 B M 01/01/2011 ## 10 11127018 53 B M 01/01/2011</code></pre> <p>We can index any set of rows or columns by constructing <em>vectors</em> of integers. In fact, the slice notation <code>:</code> is essentially doing that for a sequence of consecutive indices. You should think of vectors as lists of values with the same class.</p> <p>If we want non-consecutive indices we have other options (e.g., the <code>c</code> function, for concatenate)</p> <pre class="r"><code># non-consecutive indices using c arrest_tab[c(2,4,7,10), 1:5]</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate ## 2 11127013 37 B M 01/01/2011 ## 4 11126873 50 B M 01/01/2011 ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 ## 10 11127018 53 B M 01/01/2011</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># here's a fun one, when we call columns for a subset of rows arrest_tab[c(2,4,7,10), ]</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 2 11127013 37 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2000 Wilkens Ave ## 4 11126873 50 B M 01/01/2011 00:04 2100 Ashburton St ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 800 N Monroe St ## 10 11127018 53 B M 01/01/2011 00:15 3300 Woodland Ave ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 2 79-Other Wilkens Av & S Payson St 1 1425 ## 4 79-Other 2100 Ashburton St 1 1106 ## 7 79-Other 800 N Monroe St 1 5212 ## 10 54-Armed Person 3300 Woodland Av 1 1425 ## chargeDescription district post ## 2 Reckless Endangerment || Hand Gun Violation SOUTHERN 934 ## 4 Reg Firearm:Illegal Possession || Hgv WESTERN 735 ## 7 Handgun On Person || Handgun Violation WESTERN 724 ## 10 Reckless Endangerment || Hgv NORTHWESTERN 614 ## neighborhood Location.1 ## 2 Carrollton Ridge (39.2814026274, -76.6483635135) ## 4 Panway/Braddish Avenue (39.3117196723, -76.6623546313) ## 7 Midtown-Edmondson (39.2979815407, -76.6475113571) ## 10 Central Park Heights (39.3436773374, -76.6727297618)</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># there is also the `seq` function, to create sequences arrest_tab[seq(from=1,to=10), seq(1,10)]</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 1 11126858 23 B M 01/01/2011 00:00 ## 2 11127013 37 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2000 Wilkens Ave ## 3 11126887 46 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2800 Mayfield Ave ## 4 11126873 50 B M 01/01/2011 00:04 2100 Ashburton St ## 5 11126968 33 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 4000 Wilsby Ave ## 6 11127041 41 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 2900 Spellman Rd ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 800 N Monroe St ## 8 11126940 20 W M 01/01/2011 00:05 5200 Moravia Rd ## 9 11127051 24 B M 01/01/2011 00:07 2400 Gainsdbourgh Ct ## 10 11127018 53 B M 01/01/2011 00:15 3300 Woodland Ave ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 1 Unknown Offense 3 0233 ## 2 79-Other Wilkens Av & S Payson St 1 1425 ## 3 Unknown Offense ## 4 79-Other 2100 Ashburton St 1 1106 ## 5 Unknown Offense 1700 Aliceanna St ## 6 81-Recovered Property 2900 Spelman Rd 1 1425 ## 7 79-Other 800 N Monroe St 1 5212 ## 8 Unknown Offense 1 5200 ## 9 54-Armed Person 2400 Gainsborough Ct 1 1106 ## 10 54-Armed Person 3300 Woodland Av 1 1425</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># that is equivalent to arrest_tab[1:10,1:10]</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 1 11126858 23 B M 01/01/2011 00:00 ## 2 11127013 37 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2000 Wilkens Ave ## 3 11126887 46 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2800 Mayfield Ave ## 4 11126873 50 B M 01/01/2011 00:04 2100 Ashburton St ## 5 11126968 33 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 4000 Wilsby Ave ## 6 11127041 41 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 2900 Spellman Rd ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 800 N Monroe St ## 8 11126940 20 W M 01/01/2011 00:05 5200 Moravia Rd ## 9 11127051 24 B M 01/01/2011 00:07 2400 Gainsdbourgh Ct ## 10 11127018 53 B M 01/01/2011 00:15 3300 Woodland Ave ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 1 Unknown Offense 3 0233 ## 2 79-Other Wilkens Av & S Payson St 1 1425 ## 3 Unknown Offense ## 4 79-Other 2100 Ashburton St 1 1106 ## 5 Unknown Offense 1700 Aliceanna St ## 6 81-Recovered Property 2900 Spelman Rd 1 1425 ## 7 79-Other 800 N Monroe St 1 5212 ## 8 Unknown Offense 1 5200 ## 9 54-Armed Person 2400 Gainsborough Ct 1 1106 ## 10 54-Armed Person 3300 Woodland Av 1 1425</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># with the `seq` function you can do more sophisticated things like select only entries in odd rows (1,3,5,7...) head(arrest_tab[seq(from=1,to=nrow(arrest_tab),by=2), ])</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 1 11126858 23 B M 01/01/2011 00:00 ## 3 11126887 46 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2800 Mayfield Ave ## 5 11126968 33 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 4000 Wilsby Ave ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 800 N Monroe St ## 9 11127051 24 B M 01/01/2011 00:07 2400 Gainsdbourgh Ct ## 11 11127057 28 B M 01/01/2011 00:15 3300 Woodland Ave ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 1 Unknown Offense 3 0233 ## 3 Unknown Offense ## 5 Unknown Offense 1700 Aliceanna St ## 7 79-Other 800 N Monroe St 1 5212 ## 9 54-Armed Person 2400 Gainsborough Ct 1 1106 ## 11 54-Armed Person 3300 Woodland Av 1 1425 ## chargeDescription district post ## 1 Cds:P W/I Dist:Narc || Cds:Poss W/Intent Dist: Narc NA ## 3 Unknown Charge NORTHEASTERN 415 ## 5 Unknown Charge NORTHERN 525 ## 7 Handgun On Person || Handgun Violation WESTERN 724 ## 9 Reg Firearm:Illegal Possession || Firearms Violation NA ## 11 Reckless Endangerment || Hgv NORTHWESTERN 614 ## neighborhood Location.1 ## 1 ## 3 Belair-Edison (39.3227699160, -76.5735750473) ## 5 Pen Lucy (39.3382885254, -76.6045667070) ## 7 Midtown-Edmondson (39.2979815407, -76.6475113571) ## 9 ## 11 Central Park Heights (39.3436773374, -76.6727297618)</code></pre> <p>Now, since columns have names, we can also use strings (and vectors of strings) to index data frames.</p> <pre class="r"><code># single column arrest_tab[1:10, "age"]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 23 37 46 50 33 41 29 20 24 53</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># multiple columns arrest_tab[1:10, c("age", "sex", "race")]</code></pre> <pre><code>## age sex race ## 1 23 B M ## 2 37 B M ## 3 46 B M ## 4 50 B M ## 5 33 B M ## 6 41 B M ## 7 29 B M ## 8 20 W M ## 9 24 B M ## 10 53 B M</code></pre> <p>If we wanted a single named column from a data frame theres a special operator <code>$</code> to index:</p> <pre class="r"><code># first ten values of the age column arrest_tab$age[1:10]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 23 37 46 50 33 41 29 20 24 53</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># EXERCISE # try using three different ways of selecting rows 20 to 30 # of the "sex" column</code></pre> <p>In addition to integer indices or names, we can use vectors of logical values for indexing.</p> <pre class="r"><code># rows 2,4,7 and 10 using logical indices arrest_tab[c(FALSE,TRUE,FALSE,TRUE,FALSE,FALSE,TRUE,FALSE,FALSE,TRUE,rep(FALSE,nrow(arrest_tab)-10)),]</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 2 11127013 37 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2000 Wilkens Ave ## 4 11126873 50 B M 01/01/2011 00:04 2100 Ashburton St ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 800 N Monroe St ## 10 11127018 53 B M 01/01/2011 00:15 3300 Woodland Ave ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 2 79-Other Wilkens Av & S Payson St 1 1425 ## 4 79-Other 2100 Ashburton St 1 1106 ## 7 79-Other 800 N Monroe St 1 5212 ## 10 54-Armed Person 3300 Woodland Av 1 1425 ## chargeDescription district post ## 2 Reckless Endangerment || Hand Gun Violation SOUTHERN 934 ## 4 Reg Firearm:Illegal Possession || Hgv WESTERN 735 ## 7 Handgun On Person || Handgun Violation WESTERN 724 ## 10 Reckless Endangerment || Hgv NORTHWESTERN 614 ## neighborhood Location.1 ## 2 Carrollton Ridge (39.2814026274, -76.6483635135) ## 4 Panway/Braddish Avenue (39.3117196723, -76.6623546313) ## 7 Midtown-Edmondson (39.2979815407, -76.6475113571) ## 10 Central Park Heights (39.3436773374, -76.6727297618)</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># now here's a fun one, if we only wanted odd rows head(arrest_tab[c(TRUE,FALSE),])</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 1 11126858 23 B M 01/01/2011 00:00 ## 3 11126887 46 B M 01/01/2011 00:01 2800 Mayfield Ave ## 5 11126968 33 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 4000 Wilsby Ave ## 7 11126932 29 B M 01/01/2011 00:05 800 N Monroe St ## 9 11127051 24 B M 01/01/2011 00:07 2400 Gainsdbourgh Ct ## 11 11127057 28 B M 01/01/2011 00:15 3300 Woodland Ave ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 1 Unknown Offense 3 0233 ## 3 Unknown Offense ## 5 Unknown Offense 1700 Aliceanna St ## 7 79-Other 800 N Monroe St 1 5212 ## 9 54-Armed Person 2400 Gainsborough Ct 1 1106 ## 11 54-Armed Person 3300 Woodland Av 1 1425 ## chargeDescription district post ## 1 Cds:P W/I Dist:Narc || Cds:Poss W/Intent Dist: Narc NA ## 3 Unknown Charge NORTHEASTERN 415 ## 5 Unknown Charge NORTHERN 525 ## 7 Handgun On Person || Handgun Violation WESTERN 724 ## 9 Reg Firearm:Illegal Possession || Firearms Violation NA ## 11 Reckless Endangerment || Hgv NORTHWESTERN 614 ## neighborhood Location.1 ## 1 ## 3 Belair-Edison (39.3227699160, -76.5735750473) ## 5 Pen Lucy (39.3382885254, -76.6045667070) ## 7 Midtown-Edmondson (39.2979815407, -76.6475113571) ## 9 ## 11 Central Park Heights (39.3436773374, -76.6727297618)</code></pre> <p>The last example shows one of the most common gotchas in R. Indices are recycled. For instance if selecting rows, if you pass a logical vector thats shorter than the number of rows in the data frame, the vector will be recycled as many times as necessary to match the number of rows in the dataset. Now, why is this useful, because a pithy index vector can let you select easily. Why is this bad, because errors in code can go easily unnoticed. So in this case, the price of ease of use is paid by the programmer by having to think a lot more carefully about their code (this is a theme in R programming)</p> <p>The utility of logical indexing is that now we can select rows based on a property of its values for a given column</p> <pre class="r"><code># select rows for entities younger than 21 years old head(arrest_tab[arrest_tab$age < 21, ])</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 8 11126940 20 W M 01/01/2011 00:05 5200 Moravia Rd ## 30 11126942 20 B M 01/01/2011 01:22 1900 Ashburton Ave ## 39 11126941 20 W M 01/01/2011 02:00 300 S Bentalou St ## 41 11126955 20 B M 01/01/2011 02:20 900 Myrtle Ave ## 42 11127139 19 W M 01/01/2011 02:22 4500 Erdman Ave ## 43 11127003 20 B F 01/01/2011 02:49 2400 Brentwood St ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 8 Unknown Offense 1 5200 ## 30 79-Other 2200 Ashburton St 1 5285 ## 39 4C-Agg. Asslt.- Oth. 300 S Bentalou St 1 5200 ## 41 87-Narcotics 900 Myrtle Av 1 0573 ## 42 4E-Common Assault 4500 Erdman Av 2 0050 ## 43 75-Destruct. Of Property 500 Fallsway 1 1416 ## chargeDescription district post ## 8 Deadly Weapon-Int/Injure || Aggravated Assault NORTHEASTERN 436 ## 30 Poss Of Firearm/Ammo/Minor || Handgun Violation SOUTHWESTERN 811 ## 39 Deadly Weapon-Int/Injure || Agg Assault SOUTHWESTERN 835 ## 41 Cds: Possession-Marihuana || Possession Of Marijuana CENTRAL 122 ## 42 Dis.Erly Conduct || Assault NORTHEASTERN 431 ## 43 Assault Sec Deg-Law Enforcment || Assault EASTERN 311 ## neighborhood Location.1 ## 8 Frankford (39.3235271620, -76.5496555072) ## 30 Walbrook (39.3093667331, -76.6622965390) ## 39 Millhill (39.2836881991, -76.6526609694) ## 41 Heritage Crossing (39.2953767825, -76.6288329196) ## 42 Claremont-Freedom (39.3097342730, -76.5631244074) ## 43 Barclay (39.3163224260, -76.6104416488)</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># notice that the value of expression `arrest_tab$age < 21` # is a logical vector
# select entities (arrests) occuring in Mount Washington, # a specific neighborhood in Baltimore head(arrest_tab[arrest_tab$neighborhood == "Mount Washington",])</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age sex race arrestDate arrestTime arrestLocation ## 2334 11137346 30 B M 01/20/2011 20:00 2900 W Northern Park ## 2340 11137358 30 B M 01/20/2011 20:15 2900 W Northern Park ## 3060 11140601 26 B M 01/26/2011 20:00 5700 Pimlico Rd ## 6496 NA 22 B M 02/19/2011 23:45 0 South St ## 17993 11213825 24 B F 05/09/2011 18:30 5800 Key Ave ## 20002 11222982 21 B M 05/21/2011 01:00 5700 W Merville Ave ## incidentOffense incidentLocation charge ## 2334 24-Towed Vehicle 5600 Merville Av ## 2340 24-Towed Vehicle 5600 Merville Av 1 0573 ## 3060 87-Narcotics 5700 Pimlico Rd ## 6496 Unknown Offense ## 17993 6B-Larceny- Purse Snatch 5800 Key Av 3 4025 ## 20002 24-Towed Vehicle 5700 Merville Av ## chargeDescription district post ## 2334 Unknown Charge NORTHERN 535 ## 2340 Cds: Possession-Marihuana || Cds Violation NORTHERN 535 ## 3060 Unknown Charge NORTHERN 535 ## 6496 Unknown Charge NORTHERN 535 ## 17993 Mal Dest Prop/Valu - $500 || 2Nd Degree Assault NORTHWESTERN 635 ## 20002 Unknown Charge NORTHERN 535 ## neighborhood Location.1 ## 2334 Mount Washington (39.3563987461, -76.6763954468) ## 2340 Mount Washington (39.3563987461, -76.6763954468) ## 3060 Mount Washington (39.3597311724, -76.6715583289) ## 6496 Mount Washington (39.3608880210, -76.6641650850) ## 17993 Mount Washington (39.3585990772, -76.6792007267) ## 20002 Mount Washington (39.3587518907, -76.6759724031)</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># how about arrests where subjects are under 21 in Mount Washington? # use a logical `and` operator indices <- arrest_tab$age < 21 & arrest_tab$neighborhood == "Mount Washington"</code></pre> </div> </div> <div id="exploration" class="section level2"> <h2>Exploration</h2> <p>R has built-in functions that help easily obtain summary information about datasets. For instance:</p> <pre class="r"><code>summary(arrest_tab$sex)</code></pre> <pre><code>## A B H I U W ## 2 242 87268 1 218 1749 15048</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code>summary(arrest_tab$race)</code></pre> <pre><code>## F M ## 2 19431 85095</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># well that seems problematic # let's rename columns to correct that colnames(arrest_tab)[3:4] <- c("race", "sex")</code></pre> <p>We can also ask other useful type of summaries</p> <pre class="r"><code># What is the average age in arrests? mean(arrest_tab$age)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 33.19639</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># Median age? median(arrest_tab$age)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 30</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># what types of offenses are there summary(arrest_tab$incidentOffense)</code></pre> <pre><code>## Unknown Offense 87-Narcotics ## 38649 24744 ## 4E-Common Assault 87O-Narcotics (Outside) ## 6739 6515 ## 97-Search & Seizure 79-Other ## 3670 3461 ## 24-Towed Vehicle 6C-Larceny- Shoplifting ## 2994 1849 ## 4C-Agg. Asslt.- Oth. 55A-Prostitution ## 1556 1398 ## 4B-Agg. Asslt.- Cut 55-Disorderly Person ## 1195 923 ## 115-Trespassing 5A-Burg. Res. (Force) ## 871 847 ## 75-Destruct. Of Property 4D-Agg. Asslt.- Hand ## 686 618 ## 61-Person Wanted On War 3B-Robb Highway (Ua) ## 482 410 ## 54-Armed Person 7A-Stolen Auto ## 394 392 ## 4A-Agg. Asslt.- Gun 6D-Larceny- From Auto ## 356 336 ## 6J-Larceny- Other 3AF-Robb Hwy-Firearm ## 312 277 ## 49-Family Disturbance 26-Recovered Vehicle ## 253 249 ## 6G-Larceny- From Bldg. 20A-Followup ## 248 246 ## 78-Gambling 5D-Burg. Oth. (Force) ## 219 196 ## 3K-Robb Res. (Ua) 111-Protective Order ## 176 152 ## 4F-Assault By Threat 109-Loitering ## 152 131 ## 117-Fto 5C-Burg. Res. (Noforce) ## 130 122 ## 3AK-Robb Hwy-Knife 5B-Burg. Res. (Att.) ## 102 102 ## 81-Recovered Property 108-Liquor Law/Open Container ## 94 92 ## 3D-Robb Comm. (Ua) 2A-Rape (Force) ## 92 89 ## 6E-Larceny- Auto Acc 112-Traffic Related Incident ## 85 81 ## 23-Unauthorized Use 88-Unfounded Call ## 81 80 ## 3AO-Robb Hwy-Other Wpn 7C-Stolen Veh./Other ## 79 78 ## 2H-Indecent Exp. 1A-Murder ## 72 64 ## 71-Sex Offender Registry 48-Involuntary Detention ## 64 57 ## 114-Hindering 3AJF-Robb Carjack-Firearm ## 56 56 ## 2F-Placing Hands 73-False Pretense ## 54 54 ## 6B-Larceny- Purse Snatch 95-Exparte ## 51 51 ## 3CF-Robb Comm-Firearm 3JF-Robb Residence-Firearm ## 43 43 ## 56-Missing Person 98-Child Neglect ## 41 41 ## 3P-Robb Misc. (Ua) 58-Injured Person ## 35 35 ## 85-Mental Case 3BJ-Robb Carjack(Ua) ## 34 33 ## 5F-Burg. Oth. (Noforce) 6F-Larceny- Bicycle ## 31 31 ## 2G-Sodomy/Perverson 3JK-Robb Residence-Knife ## 30 30 ## 3CK-Robb Comm-Knife 80-Lost Property ## 25 25 ## 2B-Rape (Attempt) 29-Driving While Intox. ## 21 20 ## 3NF-Robb Misc-Firearm 5E-Burg. Oth. (Att.) ## 20 18 ## 2D-Statutory Rape 3JO-Robb Residence-Other Wpn ## 17 17 ## 67-Child Abuse-Physical 103-Dead On Arrival ## 17 15 ## 3CO-Robb Comm-Other Wpn 3NK-Robb Misc-Knife ## 15 15 ## 113-Littering 39-Fire ## 14 14 ## 76-Child Abuse-Sexual 8AO-Arson Sin Res Str-Occ ## 14 14 ## 96-Stop & Frisk 116-Public Urination / Defecation ## 14 13 ## 110-Summons Served 20H-Traffic Control ## 12 11 ## 3AJK-Robb Carjack-Knife 3GF-Robb Conv Store-Firearm ## 11 11 ## 106-Custody Dispute 52A-Animal Cruelty ## 10 10 ## 70A-Ill. Dumping 83-Discharging Firearm ## 10 10 ## 3H-Robb Conv. Stor.(Ua) 3NO-Robb Misc-Other Wpn ## 9 8 ## 93-Abduction - Other (Other) ## 8 101</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># what does summary looks like for continuous attributes? summary(arrest_tab$age)</code></pre> <pre><code>## Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. ## 0.0 23.0 30.0 33.2 43.0 87.0</code></pre> <p>Combining this type of summary with our indexing strategies we learned previously we can ask more specific questions</p> <pre class="r"><code># What is the average age for arrests in Mount Washington? mount_washington_index <- arrest_tab$neighborhood == "Mount Washington"
mean(arrest_tab$age[mount_washington_index])</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 31.10345</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># How about the number of arrests in Mount Washington _stratified_ by race and sex? table(arrest_tab$race[mount_washington_index], arrest_tab$sex[mount_washington_index])</code></pre> <pre><code>## ## F M ## 0 0 0 ## A 0 0 0 ## B 0 4 14 ## H 0 0 0 ## I 0 0 0 ## U 0 0 0 ## W 0 2 9</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code># how about a graphical summary of arrest ages in Mount Washington? # we'll use a boxplot boxplot(arrest_tab$age[mount_washington_index])</code></pre> <p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p> <pre class="r"><code># can we do the same stratified by age? boxplot(arrest_tab$age[mount_washington_index]~arrest_tab$sex[mount_washington_index])</code></pre> <p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p> <p>This used a very useful notation in R: the tilde, <code>~</code> which we will encounter in a few different places. One way of thinking about that abstractly is, do something with this attribute, as a function (or depending on, stratified by, conditioned on) this other attribute. For instance, plot <code>age</code> as a function of sex in our example.</p> <p>Lets write code thats a little cleaner for that last plot, and lets also make the plot a bit more useful by adding a title and axis labels:</p> <pre class="r"><code>mount_washington_tab <- arrest_tab[mount_washington_index,] boxplot(mount_washington_tab$age~mount_washington_tab$sex, main="Mt. Washington", xlab="Sex", ylab="Arrest Age")</code></pre> <p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p> <p>Heres one more useful plot:</p> <pre class="r"><code>barplot(table(mount_washington_tab$race), xlab="Number of Arrests", ylab="Race")</code></pre> <p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p> <div id="functions-and-conditionals" class="section level3"> <h3>Functions (and conditionals)</h3> <p>Now suppose we wanted to do a similar analysis for other neighborhoods. In that case we should encapsulate the summaries and plots we want to do in a function:</p> <pre class="r"><code>analyze_neighborhood <- function(neighborhood) { neighborhood_index <- arrest_tab$neighborhood == neighborhood neighborhood_tab <- arrest_tab[neighborhood_index,]
# actually, we only want to make the plots for neighborhoods where there are more arrests for whites than blacks, let's use a conditional expression if (sum(neighborhood_tab$race == "W") > sum(neighborhood_tab$race == "B")) {
boxplot(neighborhood_tab$age~neighborhood_tab$sex, main = neighborhood, xlab = "Sex", ylab="Arrest Age")
barplot(table(neighborhood_tab$race), main = neighborhood, xlab = "Race", ylab="Number of Arrests") } }</code></pre> <p>Now we can use that function to make our plots for specific neighborhoods</p> <pre class="r"><code>analyze_neighborhood("Mount Washington") analyze_neighborhood("Hampden")</code></pre> <p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p> </div> </div> <div id="loops" class="section level2"> <h2>Loops</h2> <p>Finally, we can use a for loop to make these plots for all neighborhoods in the dataset and save them to a pdf file</p> <pre class="r"><code>neighborhoods <- unique(arrest_tab$neighborhood)
# open a pdf file and save all plots to that file from # this point until file is closed pdf("neighborhood_analysis.pdf", width=6, height=6) for (neighborhood in neighborhoods) { analyze_neighborhood(neighborhood) } # close the pdf file (plots will now be displayed in Rstudio again) dev.off()</code></pre> <pre><code>## quartz_off_screen ## 2</code></pre> </div> <div id="next-up" class="section level2"> <h2>Next up</h2> <p>On the intricacies of vectorized operations and loops. Matrices and other numerical computing facilities.</p> </div>
</div>

3A%23fff%3Btext%2Dalign%3Acenter%3Btext%2Dshadow%3A0%201px%202px%20rgba%280%2C0%2C0%2C%2E6%29%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcaption%20%2Ebtn%7Btext%2Dshadow%3Anone%7D%40media%20screen%20and%20%28min%2Dwidth%3A768px%29%7B%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dleft%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dright%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dprev%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dnext%7Bwidth%3A30px%3Bheight%3A30px%3Bmargin%2Dtop%3A%2D15px%3Bfont%2Dsize%3A30px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dleft%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dprev%7Bmargin%2Dleft%3A%2D15px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eglyphicon%2Dchevron%2Dright%2C%2Ecarousel%2Dcontrol%20%2Eicon%2Dnext%7Bmargin%2Dright%3A%2D15px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dcaption%7Bright%3A20%25%3Bleft%3A20%25%3Bpadding%2Dbottom%3A30px%7D%2Ecarousel%2Dindicators%7Bbottom%3A20px%7D%7D%2Eclearfix%3Abefore%2C%2Eclearfix%3Aafter%2C%2Edl%2Dhorizontal%20dd%3Abefore%2C%2Edl%2Dhorizontal%20dd%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%3Abefore%2C%2Econtainer%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%2Dfluid%3Abefore%2C%2Econtainer%2Dfluid%3Aafter%2C%2Erow%3Abefore%2C%2Erow%3Aafter%2C%2Eform%2Dhorizontal%20%2Eform%2Dgroup%3Abefore%2C%2Eform%2Dhorizontal%20%2Eform%2Dgroup%3Aafter%2C%2Ebtn%2Dtoolbar%3Abefore%2C%2Ebtn%2Dtoolbar%3Aafter%2C%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%2Dvertical%3E%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%3Abefore%2C%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%2Dvertical%3E%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%3Aafter%2C%2Enav%3Abefore%2C%2Enav%3Aafter%2C%2Enavbar%3Abefore%2C%2Enavbar%3Aafter%2C%2Enavbar%2Dheader%3Abefore%2C%2Enavbar%2Dheader%3Aafter%2C%2Enavbar%2Dcollapse%3Abefore%2C%2Enavbar%2Dcollapse%3Aafter%2C%2Epager%3Abefore%2C%2Epager%3Aafter%2C%2Epanel%2Dbody%3Abefore%2C%2Epanel%2Dbody%3Aafter%2C%2Emodal%2Dfooter%3Abefore%2C%2Emodal%2Dfooter%3Aafter%7Bdisplay%3Atable%3Bcontent%3A%22%20%22%7D%2Eclearfix%3Aafter%2C%2Edl%2Dhorizontal%20dd%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%3Aafter%2C%2Econtainer%2Dfluid%3Aafter%2C%2Erow%3Aafter%2C%2Eform%2Dhorizontal%20%2Eform%2Dgroup%3Aafter%2C%2Ebtn%2Dtoolbar%3Aafter%2C%2Ebtn%2Dgroup%2Dvertical%3E%2Ebtn%2D px%29%7B%2Ehidden%2Dsm%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%7D%40media%20%28min%2Dwidth%3A992px%29%20and%20%28max%2Dwidth%3A1199px%29%7B%2Ehidden%2Dmd%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%7D%40media%20%28min%2Dwidth%3A1200px%29%7B%2Ehidden%2Dlg%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%7D%2Evisible%2Dprint%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%40media%20print%7B%2Evisible%2Dprint%7Bdisplay%3Ablock%21important%7Dtable%2Evisible%2Dprint%7Bdisplay%3Atable%7Dtr%2Evisible%2Dprint%7Bdisplay%3Atable%2Drow%21important%7Dth%2Evisible%2Dprint%2Ctd%2Evisible%2Dprint%7Bdisplay%3Atable%2Dcell%21important%7D%7D%2Evisible%2Dprint%2Dblock%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%40media%20print%7B%2Evisible%2Dprint%2Dblock%7Bdisplay%3Ablock%21important%7D%7D%2Evisible%2Dprint%2Dinline%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%40media%20print%7B%2Evisible%2Dprint%2Dinline%7Bdisplay%3Ainline%21important%7D%7D%2Evisible%2Dprint%2Dinline%2Dblock%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%40media%20print%7B%2Evisible%2Dprint%2Dinline%2Dblock%7Bdisplay%3Ainline%2Dblock%21important%7D%7D%40media%20print%7B%2Ehidden%2Dprint%7Bdisplay%3Anone%21important%7D%7D" <style type="text/css">code{white-space: pre;}</style> <link href="data:text/css;charset=utf-8,pre%20%2Eoperator%2C%0Apre%20%2Eparen%20%7B%0Acolor%3A%20rgb%28104%2C%20118%2C%20135%29%0A%7D%0Apre%20%2Eliteral%20%7B%0Acolor%3A%20%23990073%0A%7D%0Apre%20%2Enumber%20%7B%0Acolor%3A%20%23099%3B%0A%7D%0Apre%20%2Ecomment%20%7B%0Acolor%3A%20%23998%3B%0Afont%2Dstyle%3A%20italic%0A%7D%0Apre%20%2Ekeyword%20%7B%0Acolor%3A%20%23900%3B%0Afont%2Dweight%3A%20bold%0A%7D%0Apre%20%2Eidentifier%20%7B%0Acolor%3A%20rgb%280%2C%200%2C%200%29%3B%0A%7D%0Apre%20%2Estring%20%7B%0Acolor%3A%20%23d14%3B%0A%7D%0A" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" /> <script src="data:application/x-javascript;base64,"></script> <style type="text/css"> pre:not([class]) { background-color: white; } </style> <script type="text/javascript"> if (window.hljs && document.readyState && document.readyState === "complete") { window.setTimeout(function() { hljs.initHighlighting(); }, 0); } </script>

<body>
<style type="text/css"> .main-container { max-width: 940px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; } code { color: inherit; background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.04); } img { max-width:100%; height: auto; } </style> <div class="container-fluid main-container">
<div id="header"> <h1 class="title">Introduction to R (part 2)</h1> <h4 class="author"><em>CMSC320</em></h4> <h4 class="date"><em>February 4, 2016</em></h4> </div>
<div id="getting-started" class="section level2"> <h2>Getting started</h2> <p>Lets load the same data we used in the previous lab (look there for instructions on how to download).</p> <pre class="r"><code>arrest_tab <- read.csv("BPD_Arrests.csv", stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
# remember there's a naming issue in this dataset we need to fix colnames(arrest_tab)[3:4] <- c("race", "sex")</code></pre> </div> <div id="a-note-on-data-types" class="section level2"> <h2>A note on data types</h2> <p>This dataset contains data of types commonly found in data analyses</p> <ul> <li>Numeric (continuous): A numeric measurement (e.g., height)<br /> </li> <li>Numeric (discrete): Usually obtained from counting, think only integers (e.g., <code>age</code> which is measured in years)<br /> </li> <li>Categorical: One of a possible set of values (e.g., <code>sex</code>)<br /> </li> <li>Datetime: Date and time of some event or observation (e.g., <code>arrestDate</code>, <code>arrestTime</code>)<br /> </li> <li>geolocation: Latitude and Longitude of some event or observation (e.g., <code>Location.</code>)</li> </ul> <p>The distinction between continuous and discrete is a bit tricky since measurements that have finite precision must be discrete. So, the difference really comes up when we build statistical models of datasets for analysis. For now, think of discrete data as the result of counting, and continuous data the result of some physical measurement.</p> <p>We said that R is designed for data analysis. My favorite example of how that manifests itself is the <code>factor</code> datatype. If you look at your dataset now, <code>arrest_tab$sex</code> is a vector of strings:</p> <pre class="r"><code>class(arrest_tab$sex)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "character"</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code>summary(arrest_tab$sex)</code></pre> <pre><code>## Length Class Mode ## 104528 character character</code></pre> <p>However, as a measurement, or attribute, it should only take one of two values (or three depending on how you record missing, unknown or unspecified). So, in R, that categorical data type is called a <em>factor</em>. Notice what the <code>summary</code> function does after turning the <code>sex</code> attribute into a <em>factor</em>:</p> <pre class="r"><code>arrest_tab$sex <- factor(arrest_tab$sex) summary(arrest_tab$sex)</code></pre> <pre><code>## F M ## 2 19431 85095</code></pre> <p>This distinction shows up in many other places where functions have very different behavior when called on a vector of strings and when called on a factor (e.g., functions that make plots, or functions that learn statistical models).</p> <p>One last note, the possible values a <em>factor</em> can take are called <em>levels</em>:</p> <pre class="r"><code>levels(arrest_tab$sex)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "" "F" "M"</code></pre> <p>Exercise: you should transform the <code>race</code> attribute into a factor as well. How many levels does it have?</p> </div> <div id="thinking-in-vectors" class="section level2"> <h2>Thinking in vectors</h2> <p>In data analysis the <em>vector</em> is probably the most fundamental data type (other than basic numbers, strings, etc.). Why? Consider getting data about one attribute, say height, for a group of people. What do you get, an array of numbers, all in the same unit (say feet, inches or centimeters). How about their name? Then you get an array of strings. Abstractly, we think of vectors as arrays of values, all of the same <em>class</em> or datatype.</p> <p>In our dataset, each column, corresponding to an attribute, is a vector:</p> <pre class="r"><code># the 'str' function gives a bit more low-level information about objects str(arrest_tab$Location)</code></pre> <pre><code>## chr [1:104528] "" "(39.2814026274, -76.6483635135)" ...</code></pre> <p>R (and other data analysis languages) are designed to operate on vectors easily. For example, frequently we want to do some kind of transformation to a data attribute, say record age in months rather than years. Then we would perform the <strong>same operation</strong> for every value in the corresponding vector:</p> <pre class="r"><code>age_in_months <- arrest_tab$age * 12</code></pre> <p>In a language that doesnt support this type of vectorized operation, you would use a loop, or similar construct, to perform this operation.</p> <p>Another type of transformation frequently done is to combine attributes into a single attribute. Suppose we wanted to combine the <code>arrestLocation</code> and <code>neighborhood</code> attributes into an <code>address</code> attribute:</p> <pre class="r"><code># remember you can always find out what a function does by using ?paste head(paste(arrest_tab$arrestLocation, arrest_tab$neighborhood, sep=", "))</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] ", " ## [2] "2000 Wilkens Ave, Carrollton Ridge" ## [3] "2800 Mayfield Ave, Belair-Edison" ## [4] "2100 Ashburton St, Panway/Braddish Avenue" ## [5] "4000 Wilsby Ave, Pen Lucy" ## [6] "2900 Spellman Rd, Cherry Hill"</code></pre> <p>Here the <code>paste</code> function concatenates strings element-wise: the first string in <code>arrestLocation</code> is concatenated with the first string in <code>neighborhood</code>, etc.</p> <p>Arithmetic operations have the same element-wise operation:</p> <pre class="r"><code># add first 10 odd numbers to first 10 even numbers seq(1, 20, by=2) + seq(2, 20, by=2)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 3 7 11 15 19 23 27 31 35 39</code></pre> </div> <div id="functions-as-values-and-vectorized-operations" class="section level2"> <h2>Functions as values and vectorized operations</h2> <p>Now here is where we see the value of using a <em>functional language</em> for data analysis. In data analysis, when you want to perform some operation on a vector of values, a very common coding pattern that arises is to (a) define a function that takes one value, and returns one value, and then (b) <em>apply</em> this function to every entry in the vector.</p> <p>Heres one example: suppose we want to create a new attribute that specifies if the person arrested is under-age (younger that 18). We can (a) define a function that takes an age, and the uses a conditional (if statement) to return youth or adult depending on the age.</p> <pre class="r"><code>make_age_categorical <- function(age) { if (age < 18) { "youth" } else { "adult" } }</code></pre> <p>A couple of notes about functions in R based on this example. This function has a single <em>expression</em>, the <code>if</code> statement. The <em>result</em> of evaluating this expression is either <code>"youth"</code> or <code>"adult"</code>. So the <em>value</em> of the <code>if</code> statement is going to be a string. Notice also, that there is no <code>return</code> statement in this function. The result of calling a function is the <em>value</em> of the last <em>expression</em> in the function definition.</p> <p>Now that we have a function in place, we can <em>apply</em> this function to the <code>age</code> attribute in our dataset to get our new categorical age attribute:</p> <pre class="r"><code>categorical_age <- sapply(arrest_tab$age, make_age_categorical) str(categorical_age)</code></pre> <pre><code>## chr [1:104528] "adult" "adult" "adult" "adult" "adult" ...</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code>table(categorical_age)</code></pre> <pre><code>## categorical_age ## adult youth ## 104065 463</code></pre> <p>Every functional language has a function like <code>sapply</code>: it takes a vector (or list) and a function and applies the function to each entry in the vector.</p> <p>Now, as you may imagine, the type of transformation we did here is a pattern that is used very frequently in data analysis. R has operations (the <code>ifelse</code> function) to make this easier:</p> <pre class="r"><code># ifelse takes a vector of logical values and returns one of two options based on the result
categorical_age <- ifelse(arrest_tab$age < 18, "youth", "adult") str(categorical_age)</code></pre> <pre><code>## chr [1:104528] "adult" "adult" "adult" "adult" "adult" ...</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code>table(categorical_age)</code></pre> <pre><code>## categorical_age ## adult youth ## 104065 463</code></pre> <p>This is again a vectorized operation. As we progress through the semester we will see value of thinking with vectors, vectorized operations and applying functions as we do data analysis.</p> </div> <div id="side-effects-and-functional-languages" class="section level2"> <h2>Side-effects and functional languages</h2> <p>Another fundamental design decision in R, as a functional language, is that functions <em>should</em> have no <em>side-effects</em>. Lets look at a simple example</p> <pre class="r"><code>x <- 2 f <- function(x) { x <- 6 x } f(x)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 6</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code>x</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 2</code></pre> <p>In this case, the assignment <code>x <- 6</code> inside function <code>f</code> has no effect on the value of variable <code>x</code> outside function <code>f</code>. In that case, assignment <code>x <- 6</code> has no side-effects.</p> <p>This is a desirable property for data analysis because it is much easier to reason about programs when functions have no <em>side-effects</em>. On the other hand, this can have a detrimental result in performance. We will explore this issue in more detail later in the course.</p> <p>One last thing, the <code><<-</code> assignment operator lets you break this rule. <strong>DONT USE IT</strong> (unless you really need to, and in that case, you should really think again about your function design to make sure you actually need to).</p> <pre class="r"><code>x <- 2 g <- function(x) { x <<- 6 x } g(x)</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 6</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code>x</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] 6</code></pre> <div id="lists-vs.vectors" class="section level3"> <h3>Lists vs.vectors</h3> <p>We saw that vectors are arrays of values, all of the same <em>class</em>. R also allows arrays of values that have different <em>class</em> or datatype. These are called <em>lists</em>. Here is a list containing a string, and a couple of numbers:</p> <pre class="r"><code>my_list <- list("Hector", 40, 71) my_list</code></pre> <pre><code>## [[1]] ## [1] "Hector" ## ## [[2]] ## [1] 40 ## ## [[3]] ## [1] 71</code></pre> <p>Indexing in lists uses different syntax from the indexing we saw before. To index an element in a list we would use a double-bracket <code>[[</code>.</p> <pre class="r"><code>my_list[[1]]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "Hector"</code></pre> <p>In contrast, the single bracket <code>[</code> indexes a <em>part</em> of the list, and thus returns another list.</p> <pre class="r"><code>my_list[1]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [[1]] ## [1] "Hector"</code></pre> <p>That way we can use slice notation and other operations we saw when indexing vectors as before, but we get lists as results.</p> <pre class="r"><code>my_list[1:2]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [[1]] ## [1] "Hector" ## ## [[2]] ## [1] 40</code></pre> <p>List elements can have names as well:</p> <pre class="r"><code>named_list <- list(person="Hector", age=40, height=71) named_list</code></pre> <pre><code>## $person ## [1] "Hector" ## ## $age ## [1] 40 ## ## $height ## [1] 71</code></pre> <p>Which we can use to index elements as well (both with <code>[[</code> and <code>$</code>)</p> <pre class="r"><code>named_list[["person"]]</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "Hector"</code></pre> <pre class="r"><code>named_list$person</code></pre> <pre><code>## [1] "Hector"</code></pre> <p>Lists can hold arbitrary objects as elements. For example you can have a vector of strings as an element in a list</p> <pre class="r"><code>my_list <- list(person=c("Hector", "Ringo", "Paul", "John"), 40, 71) my_list</code></pre> <pre><code>## $person ## [1] "Hector" "Ringo" "Paul" "John" ## ## [[2]] ## [1] 40 ## ## [[3]] ## [1] 71</code></pre> <p>Now, we come to a momentous occassion in understanding R. <code>data.frame</code>s are special instances of <em>lists</em>! But, in this case, every element in the list is a vector, and all vectors have exactly the same length. So <code>arrest_tab$age</code> indexes the named element <code>age</code> in the list <code>arrest_tab</code>!</p> <p>The pattern of <em>applying</em> functions to entries in vectors also holds for elements in lists. So, if we want to calculate smallest value for every attribute in our dataset, we could do something like this:</p> <pre class="r"><code>sapply(arrest_tab, function(v) sort(v)[1])</code></pre> <pre><code>## arrest age race ## "11126858" "0" "" ## sex arrestDate arrestTime ## "1" "01/01/2011" "00:00" ## arrestLocation incidentOffense incidentLocation ## "" "102-Questional Death" "" ## charge chargeDescription district ## "" "" "" ## post neighborhood Location.1 ## "111" "" ""</code></pre> </div> </div> <div id="matrices" class="section level2"> <h2>Matrices</h2> <p>The last important data structure Ill talk about in this introduction are matrices. One way of thinking about them is as <em>rectangular</em> data structures - they have two dimensions, rows and columns, like data tables - but only holds values of a single <em>class</em> or data type.</p> <pre class="r"><code>my_mat <- matrix(1:20, nrow=4, ncol=5) my_mat</code></pre> <pre><code>## [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [,5] ## [1,] 1 5 9 13 17 ## [2,] 2 6 10 14 18 ## [3,] 3 7 11 15 19 ## [4,] 4 8 12 16 20</code></pre> <p>These are important data structures in Machine Learning and statistics since most of the learning and analysis algorithms we will learn about assume that you can represent data as a matrix. Also, storage for these data structures is much more compact than data tables and lists. Since all elements are of the same <em>class</em> or type, language designers can be much smarter about how to lay out this data in memory.</p> </div>
</div>
